file_content.text: Good luck hunting Skavak, Captain. That cheat deserves whatever he gets from you.
Jiik and Juul told me Skavak went into the Works. Be careful down there, Captain.
Juul contacted me about her brother. If you don't free him from the Justicars, you'll never find Skavak.
The Justicars' territory isn't friendly to non-humans, but I'm afraid that's where your contacts are. Good luck.
Your contacts are in the Justicars' territory. They're good people, Captain. Treat them well.
Looks like your efforts have paid off, Captain. My informants just witnessed Skavak fighting someone and fleeing into Justicars' territory. We have him!
Who are these "Justicars"?
Justicars?
They're vigilantes--self-appointed "judges" of a whole city sector. Executioners is more like it.
Did your informants say who Skavak was fighting?
There was a fight?
An alien of some sort, according to this report. Very peculiar.
Tell me where I'm going, Darmas.
Not yet.
You're headed into one of the most dangerous parts of Coruscant.
The Justicars don't tolerate outsiders in their sector. Skavak must truly be desperate to risk his life going there.
I'm not letting some Justicar kill Skavak before I do.
I want him first.
Then you'd better hurry. Justicars aren't known for their mercy.
Justicars don't sound so bad.
Don't bet on it. They've been known to "punish" non-humans simply for being alien.
You'll want to avoid the Justicars unless you're particularly hungry for a fight. They're all ex-soldiers and armed to the teeth.
He's a scared little man running out of options.
I left him no choice.
It would seem so. Justicars are heavily armed ex-soldiers. It's no exaggeration calling them an army.
My informants are a brother and sister named Jiik and Juul. They know where to find Skavak. I'll tell them you're coming.
Play your hand carefully in the Justicar sector. My instincts tell me Skavak hasn't shown all his cards yet.
You've been a real prince, Darmas. I won't forget it.
You've helped a lot.
Skavak won't get away from me this time.
Time to settle this.
I'll keep that in mind.
He can play all he wants.
I hope this isn't the last we'll see of each other. I can't help feeling there's more to our relationship than revenge on Skavak.
You think a starship captain like me and a gambler like you would ever work out?
Like what?
Why not? I think we complement each other well.
I think you'll see me again before you know it.
[Flirt] I agree.
I certainly hope so.
Sorry, but you're way too old for me.
In your dreams, grandpa.
Hmph. I must be losing my touch. Maybe it really is time to retire.
Good luck to you, Captain. I hope you make Skavak pay all his debts.
Having some trouble with bounty hunters, Captain?
I can't help it if I'm popular with all the wrong people.
Only a little.
Don't sell yourself short, my dear. All the right people find you charming, too.
Being famous has its drawbacks, doesn't it?
Got anything for me about Skavak?
Any news?
He's still hiding beneath whatever rock he crawled under--but I expect that will change soon.
You're supposed to know everything. Why didn't you warn me about them?
You should have helped.
I didn't see those wild cards coming until it was too late. Fortunately, you trumped them.
I hear Black Sun's on an emergency recruitment drive, and you had an altercation at the spaceport. I take it my lead was worthwhile.
Turns out there's a Sullustan lawman chasing Skavak, too.
There was a potential ally.
It's always good to have friends with common interests.
No matter how close I get, I still can't catch Skavak. I need the best information you've got.
Give me more.
You're receiving it, I assure you. These things take time.
Skavak will be writhing on the floor before this is over.
I'm tightening the noose.
That's quite the vicious streak. It seems he brings out the worst in people.
While we wait for Skavak to make his next move, perhaps we could play a little sabacc?
I saw that one coming....
Corso, don't be such a spoilsport. What do you say, Captain? First game's on me.
We could both use a relaxing diversion. The first game's on me. What do you say?
What's the harm in a friendly game of cards?
As long as you're buying.
Sabacc is the sport of spacers--everyone who's anyone plays it. I'll deal the cards....
I was hoping we'd have the chance to get better acquainted.
[Flirt] Just the two of us?
That sounds delightful. I'd love to hear all about you, my dear.
I may have been a bit hasty when I said we could trust Darmas....
I prefer a man with some life experience.
I like older men.
Right. I, uh, think I'll leave you two alone.
Nobody's going to replace you, farm boy.
You're still tops, Corso.
Oh. Uh, that's good. I mean... what are we talking about?
On second thought, how about we play a little pazaak?
I shouldn't be doing this.
I'm afraid I've never been a fan. Its strategy has always felt a bit shallow.
Please don't spare any details.
Sit back and relax. This might take a while.
I won't.
I'll just put a "do not disturb" sign outside so we can talk as long as we like....
Well, that was highly informative. I'm already looking forward to our future discussions.
Who knew playing cards could be so much fun?
Me, too.
I did, obviously.
Sorry, but there's only one thing on my mind right now.
Back to business.
Yes, I can see you're eager to continue your other manhunt.
That's all you're ever going to know about me.
There won't be any.
Care to place a wager on that?
What do you know about our mutual friend?
I'm interested in Corso.
Corso? He's, ah, well... let's just call him "uncomplicated" and leave it at that.
Do you honestly think you have a chance with me?
Don't get your hopes up.
Playing hard to get, hmm? I know that game, too.
I play to win, Darmas. Hope you can keep up with me.
You're on, old man.
Don't say I didn't warn you, Captain.
Get us a round of drinks, won't you, Corso? There's a good man. Let's deal some cards....
Always a pleasure to meet a new challenger....
You win again. That was... very impressive.
Impressive? The captain just cleaned your chrono, Darmas.
Hmm. I'd say you've played this game before.
I never said I was a beginner.
Maybe I have.
Then I'm a victim of my assumptions. Well played, my friend.
I just played the cards I was dealt.
It was all luck.
Pleading beginner's luck? I'm not sure if that's better or worse.
If you're tops around here, the other players must really be lousy.
I thought you were good.
I clearly need to seek out fresh competition.
All I care about is getting my ship back.
I'm not in the mood.
As you wish--but you don't know what you're missing.
I beg your forgiveness, but there's a Neimoidian who's been requesting a round of sabacc from me all day. I really shouldn't disappoint him....
Ah, that was time well spent. I do love the smell of fresh credits.
Until I get my ship back, my earning potential is pretty limited.
Wish I had my ship.
You worry too much. A smart spacer always finds a way to turn a profit.
Maybe I should take up sabacc to pay the bills.
So do I.
There's a reason they call it the "sport of spacers," my friend.
I'm sick of wasting time in this cantina.
You're boring me.
Relax, my friend. You've practically worn a groove in the floor.
Hold on, I'm receiving an alert from my network. This may be what we've been waiting for....
I'll continue to gather information. We'll find Skavak, I promise.
Black Sun is notorious for keeping holorecordings of all their meetings. No doubt they've preserved the highlights of Skavak's visit.
I doubt Black Sun lets just anybody peek at their holos.
Holorecordings, huh?
What a flimsy lead.
Black Sun made a fortune extorting corrupt officials using their holorecordings. Nowadays, the gang records everything "just in case."
Bring me up to speed on this gang.
Black Sun?
After the Empire sacked Coruscant, the worst criminal scum organized and called themselves Black Sun. A bit theatrical, if you ask me.
Black Sun fragments its recordings over several computers to prevent unauthorized viewing. You'll have to assemble the relevant footage by accessing each computer.
I should warn you, Black Sun controls an entire sector of Coruscant. They're thugs with the most horrible manners. Do be careful. Good luck.
An informant spotted you leaving the Migrant Merchants' Guild. I trust Kixi was useful?
Kixi did a real number on Skavak's identity record.
She was indeed.
On a world this crowded with people and technology, he can't hide for long.
I have a better idea what Skavak is up to, but still no clue where he is.
A little.
At least you know where he isn't.
She was useless. Didn't know where Skavak went.
Not at all.
Sorry to hear that. Sometimes, the process of elimination is painful--but cheer up.
My sources reveal Skavak is doing business with the Black Sun gang. A dangerous friendship for all sorts of reasons.
I don't know anything new yet, Captain.
Skavak recently used the services of a data slicer named Kixi in the Migrant Merchants' Guild headquarters. Quite talented, I hear.
What would Skavak need with a data slicer?
Data slicer?
Slicers are masters at cracking codes and manipulating data. Miscreant like Skavak'll have all sorts of nefarious uses for such talent.
I'll say this: The man has a way with women.
More of Skavak's girlfriends.
I don't think it's a romantic relationship. Skavak doesn't cavort with aliens--even near-humans like Kixi.
What do you know about this guild?
Migrant Merchants' Guild?
It's made up of aliens who lost their homes in the war. The guild's original goal was self-preservation, but lately they've become... greedy.
Kixi might be able to help you flush Skavak out of hiding. Be careful, though--the guild is well armed and doesn't like outsiders.
Excuse me, darling, but there's a Chagrian with more credits than sense. I really shouldn't let him leave with all his money.
Excuse me, but I notice some delightful young ladies in desperate need of attention. Duty calls.
Forgive me for being so forward, but you're more radiant than a Tatooine sunset. Darmas Pollaran, at your service.
I'm sure you say that to all the girls.
Right.
Nonsense, my dear. I can't remember the last time this dark cantina seemed so bright and lively.
Give it up, old man. She's not your type.
Ah, Corso. Good to see you in person, my boy.
You're even better-looking in person, Darmas.
[Flirt] Charmed, I'm sure.
Come on, Captain. Isn't he a little old for you?
Don't listen to the boy. Feel free to compliment me any time.
Darmas, you're slicker than a greased Hutt.
Oh, brother.
She's got your number, old man.
You wound me. I meant that compliment from the bottom of my heart.
Welcome, my friend. I'm Darmas Pollaran, sabacc player and information resource without equal.
Nice to meet you. I'm the fastest blaster in the galaxy.
I can top that.
I guess congratulations are in order. I wasn't aware that competition had been settled. Good for you.
You seem to have a lot of female admirers.
Who are these women?
Women seem to find me irresistible. Just one more way I'm an extremely fortunate man.
Skip it, pal.
You'll find a little politeness goes a long way in the shadows of Coruscant. Try it some time.
Sorry to hear about Viidu. He was a man of refined tastes and a terrible card player. I'll truly miss him.
Life is like sabacc. The trick is to quit while you're ahead and enjoy your winnings--exactly how I'll spend my twilight years.
I'll still be flying around this galaxy a hundred years from now.
I plan to never die.
Ha! I like your spirit, Captain. Sometimes I think I'm already too old for this business.
I can't imagine a handsome man like you living as a hermit.
[Flirt] Not all alone, I hope.
Perish the thought. I simply have to convince the right woman to come with me. If you have any recommendations, let me know.
I'll drink to that.
Who needs luck? With the right preparation and a flexible strategy, a man can be ready for anything life throws at him--even death.
Looks to me like you're already in your twilight years.
You mean now?
Really? Good thing I'm having such a wonderful time, then.
Now, I know this isn't a social call. Corso says you have troubles, and I'm prepared to help.
A man named Skavak stole my freighter and brought it here.
Tell me where to find my ship.
Corso mentioned a cargo hold full of stolen blasters and the infamous Rogun the Butcher, too. My sympathies.
I want payback on a man named Skavak.
I need revenge, not help.
Yes, Corso was equally emphatic about that. Having met Skavak, I understand completely.
Rogun the Butcher put a bounty on my head. I want it removed.
Get a gangster off my back.
Not much I can do about that, except find the man who got you into trouble. Name is Skavak, yes?
Skavak is well known in the galactic underworld. He's earned death sentences across the galaxy for everything from armed robbery to kidnapping.
He's known to be in the Sith Empire's pocket, and he even cheats at cards. I'm happy to help you find him.
If there's one thing I hate, it's a card cheat.
A thief and a cheater.
Oh, my... beauty, intelligence and fine moral values--what's not to like about that combination?
In my book, if you can only win by cheating you shouldn't be playing the game at all.
Skavak works for the Empire?
He deals with Sith?
On occasion, yes. The man isn't particular about his friends. Let's hope that makes him easier to catch.
So point me at him, already.
Patience, my friend. Your enemy has more than one associate here. We need to plan our search carefully, or he'll escape again.
Soon as Corso mentioned Skavak's name, I alerted all my best informants. I'm getting some interesting leads.
What did I tell you, Captain? Darmas can find out anything. We'll have Skavak in no time.
How much do you want for your information, Darmas?
At what cost?
This information is free of charge, my dear. I would never consider extorting credits from a beautiful woman in distress.
Nothing, my friend. I couldn't live with myself, taking advantage of a man who lost his starship.
Let's hear Darmas's brilliant advice, first.
We'll see.
I don't offer advice, Captain--only information. What you do with it is up to you.
Viidu said the same thing--and look what happened to him.
I've heard that before.
Viidu, good as he was, lacked my particular gift for conversation--not to mention my vast network of contacts.
Greetings, Captain. I was expecting my old friend Corso, as well. What I have to say is for both of you.
Care to try your luck at sabacc? I promise to go easy on you for the first hand, heh....
My sources revealed two places to start your hunt for Skavak. First, he recently paid a visit to the Black Sun gang.
There's a trio of well-armed youths outside asking for you. Not sure what they want.
I hear Black Sun is on an emergency recruitment drive. Nicely done. You should still talk to Kixi in the Migrant Merchants' Guild.
The captain and I can handle them. What's your other lead?
Come see me after you visit Black Sun and the Migrant Merchants' Guild. Good luck, Captain.
Nobody deals with Skavak except me, understood?
Find him, but don't touch him.
Absolutely. I've never felt the urge to pull a trigger, not when others have so much more enthusiasm.
You're a good man to have around, Darmas.
[Flirt] Thanks for everything.
When this is all over, maybe we can discuss other ways I can be of assistance?
I'm holding you to that promise, pal.
Don't let me down.
I've never failed to provide useful information and I don't plan to start now.
If I regret this, you're dead.
Throttle down, Captain. Darmas is a friend. He wouldn't hurt us.
It's alright, Corso. If I'd been through what the captain has I'd be paranoid, too.
